name: Css

aliases.name: BackgroundBlendMode
aliases.comment:
Because `color` is both a common propertie and common value
in CSS (e.g. `color: red` with and `background-blend-mode: color`),
we implement it as a property (for the `color: red` case) and allow it to
be used as a value as well. When being used as a value, we call it, expect
that it will return the desired String as its key, and use that as our value.
(See `getOverloadedProperty`. Note that `VerticalAlign`.)

aliases.name: NonMixable
aliases.comment:
A [`ColorValue`](#ColorValue) that does not have `red`, `green`, or `blue`
values.

aliases.name: VerticalAlign
aliases.comment:
Because `top` and `bottom` are both common properties and common values
in CSS (e.g. `top: 5px` with `position: absolute` and `vertical-align: top`),
we implement it as a property (for the `top: 5px` case) and allow it to
be used as a value as well. When being used as a value, we call it, expect
that it will return the desired String as its key, and use that as our value.
(See `getOverloadedProperty`. Note that `TextAlign` follows a similar pattern.)

values.name: absolute
values.comment:
An `absolute` [`position`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/position) value.

values.name: active
values.comment:

values.name: after
values.comment:
An [`::after`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3A%3Aafter)

values.name: alignItems
values.comment:
Sets [`align-items`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/align-items).

**Note:** `auto` is not currently supported here. If you need to set this property to `auto`,
use this workaround:

property "align-items" "auto"

If this is annoying, please file an issue, so adding support for "auto"
can be prioritized!

values.name: alignSelf
values.comment:
Sets [`align-self`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/align-self).

**Note:** `auto` is not currently supported here. If you need to set this property to `auto`,
use this workaround:

property "align-self" "auto"

If this is annoying, please file an issue, so adding support for "auto"
can be prioritized!

values.name: batch
values.comment:
Create a style from multiple other styles.

    underlineOnHover =
        batch
            [ textDecoration none

            , hover
                [ textDecoration underline ]
            ]

    css
        [ color (rgb 128 64 32)
        , underlineOnHover
        ]

...has the same result as:

    css
        [ color (rgb 128 64 32)
        , textDecoration none
        , hover
            [ textDecoration underline ]
        ]

values.name: calc
values.comment:
The css [calc](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/CSS/calc) function.

    almostPct100 =
        calc (pct 100) minus (px 2)


    -- calc(100vh - (2px + 2rem))
    screenMinusBorderAndFooter =
        calc (vh 100) minus (calc (px 2) plus (rem 2))

    myWidth =
        width almostPct100

    myHeight =
        height screenMinusBorderAndFooter

Using \* and / with calc isn't supported. Use arithmetics from elm instead.
values.type: Css.Calc compatibleA -> Css.CalcExpression -> Css.Calc compatibleB -> Css.CalculatedLength

values.name: capitalize
values.comment: `capitalize` [`text-transform`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-transform#Values) value

values.name: center
values.comment:
`center` [alignment](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-align).
Can also be used with flex-box's align-items and justify-content properties to apply the value of center

values.name: ch
values.comment: [`ch`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/length#ch) units.

A [`:checked`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3Achecked)

values.comment: [`cm`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/length#cm) units.

values.comment:
A `collapse` [border-collapse](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/border-collapse#Values).
This can also represent a `collapse` [`visibility`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/visibility#Values).

values.comment: The `color-dodge` [`blend-mode`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/blend-mode#color-dodge).

values.name: columnReverse

The[`column-reverse`](<https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-direction> #Values) value for the
flex-direction property.

values.name: contain
values.comment: The `contain` [`background-size`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-size) value.

values.name: content
values.comment:
The [`content`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-basis#Values) value for the

values.name: contentBox
values.comment:
The `content-box` value for the [`box-sizing`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/box-sizing) property.
Can also be used as `content-box` value for the [`background-clip`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-clip) property.

values.name: cover
values.comment: The `cover` [`background-size`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-size) value.

values.name: currentColor

The [`currentColor`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color_value#currentColor_keyword)

values.comment:
A [`cursor`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/cursor#Values)
specifies the mouse cursor displayed when mouse pointer is over an element.

values.comment: The `darken` [`blend-mode`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/blend-mode#darken).

values.comment: For `display: flex`, use [`displayFlex`](#displayFlex).

values.comment:
`display: flex`. This works around the fact that
[`flex` is already taken](#flex).

An [`:empty`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3Aempty)
[pseudo-class](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Pseudo-classes).

values.name: enabled

An [`:enabled`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3Aenabled)
[pseudo-class](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Pseudo-classes).

values.comment: `end` [alignment](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-align).

values.name: ex
values.comment: [`ex`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/length#ex) units.

values.comment: The `exclusion` [`blend-mode`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/blend-mode#exclusion).

values.comment: Alias for `off` value of [`font-feature-settings`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings#Formal_syntax)

values.name: featureOn
values.comment: Alias for `on` value of [`font-feature-settings`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings#Formal_syntax)

values.name: featureTag
values.comment:
Creates a [`feature-tag-value`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings#feature-tag-value)
with the default value of `1`

    fontFeatureSettings (featureTag "hist")

values.name: featureTag2
values.comment:
Creates a [`feature-tag-value`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings#feature-tag-value)
with a particular integer value

    fontFeatureSettings (featureTag2 "smcp" on)

    fontFeatureSettings (featureTag2 "swsh" 2)

values.comment:
The `fill-available` value for
[`min-width`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/min-width#Values),
[`max-width`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/max-width#Values),
[`min-height`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/min-height#Values), and
[`max-height`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/max-height#Values)

values.name: fillBox
values.comment: The `fill-box` value for the [`transform-box`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-box) property.

values.comment:
A [`:first`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3Afirst)
[pseudo-class](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Pseudo-classes).

A [`:first-child`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3Afirst-child)
[pseudo-class](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Pseudo-classes).

A [`::first-letter`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3A%3Afirst-letter)

[pseudo-element](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Pseudo-elements).

A [`:first-of-type`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3Afirst-of-type)

The `fit-content` value for
[`min-width`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/min-width#Values),

values.name: fixed
values.comment:
A `fixed` [`position`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/position) value.
This can also represent a `fixed` [`background-attachment`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/background-attachment) value.

    position fixed

This can also be the `fixed` value for [`table-layout`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/table-layout#Values).
values.type: { value : String.String, position : Css.Compatible, backgroundAttachment : Css.Compatible, tableLayout : Css.Compatible }

values.name: flat
values.comment: The `flat` value for the [`transform-style`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-style) property.

values.name: flex
values.comment:
Sets [`flex`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex) property.

flex (none | content | auto | (int 1) | (px 10))
flex2 (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10 ))
flex3 (int 1) (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10))

values.name: flex2
values.comment:
Sets [`flex`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex) property.

flex (none | content | auto | (int 1) | (px 10))
flex2 (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10 ))
flex3 (int 1) (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10))

values.name: flex3
values.comment:
Sets [`flex`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex) property.

flex (none | content | auto | (int 1) | (px 10))
flex2 (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10 ))
flex3 (int 1) (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10))
values.type: Css.Number compatibleA -> Css.Number compatibleB -> Css.LengthOrNumber compatibleC -> Css.Style

values.name: flexBasis
values.comment:
Sets [`flex-basis`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-basis) property.

flex (none | content | auto | (int 1) | (px 10))
flex2 (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10 ))
flex3 (int 1) (int 1) ((int 1) | (px 10))

values.name: flexDirection
values.comment: Sets [`flex-direction`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-direction) property.

values.name: flexEnd
values.comment:
The[`flex-end`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/align-items#Values) value for the
align-items property.
Can also be used with flex-box's justify-content property to apply the value of flex-end.

values.name: flexFlow1
values.comment:
Sets [`flex-flow`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-flow) property.

flexFlow1 (wrap | wrapReverse | noWrap)
flexFlow2 (wrap | wrapReverse | noWrap) (row | column | rowReverse | columnReverse)

Or vice versa, order is not important for flex-flow

values.name: flexFlow2
values.comment:
Sets [`flex-flow`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-flow) property.

flexFlow1 (wrap | wrapReverse | noWrap)
flexFlow2 (wrap | wrapReverse | noWrap) (row | column | rowReverse | columnReverse)

Or vice versa, order is not important for flex-flow

values.name: flexGrow
values.comment: Sets [`flex-grow`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-grow) property.

values.name: flexShrink
values.comment: Sets [`flex-shrink`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-shrink) property.

values.name: flexStart
values.comment:
The[`flex-start`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/align-items#Values) value for the
align-items property.
Can also be used with flex-box's justify-content property to apply the value of flex-start.

values.name: flexWrap
values.comment: Sets [`flex-wrap`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-wrap) property.

values.name: float
values.comment:
Sets ['float'](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/float)
float : Float compatible -> Style

    float right

values.name: focus
values.comment:
A [`:focus`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/%3Afocus)
[pseudo-class](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Pseudo-classes).

values.name: fontFamilies
values.comment:
For multiple font families:

    fontFamilies [ "Verdana", "Arial" ]

    fontFamilies [ qt "Gill Sans Extrabold", "Helvetica", .value sansSerif ]

values.name: fontFamily
values.comment:
For when your font is one of [`serif`](#serif), [`sansSerif`](#sansSerif), [`monospace`](#monospace), [`cursive`](#cursive) or [`fantasy`](#fantasy).
If you want to refer to a font by its name (like Helvetica or Arial), use [`fontFamilies`](#fontFamilies) instead.

values.name: fontFeatureSettings
values.comment:
Sets [`font-feature-settings`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings)

    fontFeatureSettings (featureTag "hist")

    fontFeatureSettings (featureTag2 "smcp" on)

    fontFeatureSettings (featureTag2 "swsh" 2)

values.name: fontFeatureSettingsList
values.comment:
Sets [`font-feature-settings`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-feature-settings)

    fontFeatureSettingsList [ featureTag "c2sc", featureTag "smcp" ]

values.name: fontSize
values.comment:
Sets [`font-size`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-size)

    fontSize xxSmall

    fontSize (px 12)

values.name: fontStyle
values.comment:
Sets [`font-style`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-style)

    fontStyle italic

values.name: hex
values.comment:

in hexadecimal notation. You can optionally include `#` as the first character,
for benefits like syntax highlighting in editors, ease of copy/pasting from
tools which express these as e.g. `#abcdef0`, etc.

values.name: hidden
values.comment:
`hidden` [`overflow`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/overflow#Values) value.

This can also represent a `hidden` [border style](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/border-style#Values),
as well as a `hidden` [`visibility`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/visibility#Values).

values.name: hsl
values.comment:
[HSL color value](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/color_value#hsl())
`s` and `l` values are expressed as a number between 0 and 1 and are converted
to the appropriate percentage at compile-time

values.name: hsla

values.comment:
Define a custom property.

    css [ property "-webkit-font-smoothing" "none" ]

...outputs

    -webkit-font-smoothing: none;

values.name: pseudoClass
values.comment:
Define a custom pseudo-class.

This can be useful for deprecated pseudo-classes such as `-moz-any-link`, which
[has been deprecated and removed](https://www.fxsitecompat.com/en-CA/docs/2016/any-link-css-pseudo-class-has-been-unprefixed/)
in modern browsers.

    button
        [ css [ pseudoClass "-moz-any-link" [ color (hex "f00") ] ] ]
        [ text "Whee!" ]

...outputs

    <button class="f9fcb2">Whee!</button>

    <style>
        .f9fcb2:-moz-any-link {
            color: #f00;
        }
    </style>

values.name: pseudoElement
values.comment:
Define a custom pseudo-element.

    textarea
        [ css [ pseudoElement "-webkit-scrollbar" [ display none ] ] ]
        []

...outputs

    <textarea class="d84ff7"></textarea>

    <style>
        .d84ff7::-webkit-scrollbar {
            display: none;
        }
    </style>

values.name: thick
values.comment:
The
[border width values](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/border-width)
of `thin`, `medium`, and `thick` have unspecified behavior according to the
CSS specification, and as such are intentionally unsupported.

Using them is a bad idea, but if the fate of the world depends on it, you can
fall back on something like this:

    css [ property "border-left" "thick" ]

[border width values](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/border-width)

Using them is a bad idea, but if the fate of the world depends on it, you can
fall back on something like this:

touchAction (auto | none | panX | panLeft | panRight | panY | panUp | panDown | pinchZoom | manipulation | inherit | initial | unset)

values.name: transform
values.comment:
Sets [`transform`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform)
with a single explicit transform value. If you need to set the transform
property to `none`, use the `transforms` function with an empty list. See
`transforms` for more details.

    transform (scaleX 1.4)

values.name: transformBox
values.comment: The [`transform-box`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-box) property.

values.name: transformStyle
values.comment: The [`transform-style`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-style) property.

values.name: transforms
values.comment:
Sets [`transform`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform)
with a series of transform-functions. If an empty list is provided, the CSS
output will be `none`, as if to state directly that the set of transforms
applied to the current selector is empty:

    transforms [] -- transform: none;

In the case that only one transform is needed, the `transform` function may be
used instead for convenience. `transform` expects exactly one transform-function
and cannot be passed `none`:

    transform (matrix 1 2 3 4 5 6) -- transform: matrix(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6);

If a collection of transforms is needed, use the `transforms` function with a
populated list:

    transforms [ perspective 1, scale2 1 1.4 ]

name: Css.Animations
comment:
# Animations

@docs Property, keyframes, Keyframes


# Animatable Properties

As [MDN explains](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_animated_properties), only certain CSS properties are animatable.

Some of the animatable properties (except for experimental properties, or properties with browser prefixes) are listed here. Many of them share a name and similar type with `Style` equivalents in the `Css` module, but they are different in that unlike `Style`s, animatable properties [are not compatible with `!important`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@keyframes#!important_in_a_keyframe) or various selectors or media queries.

**NOTE:** We're looking to expand this list, but only on the `phantom-types` branch! See <https://github.com/rtfeldman/elm-css/issues/392>

@docs opacity, transform, all, backgroundSize, backgroundSize2, border, property, backgroundColor, border2, border3, borderBottom, borderBottom2, borderBottom3, custom

aliases.name: Keyframes
aliases.type: { compatible | keyframes : Css.Structure.Compatible, none : Css.Structure.Compatible, value : String.String }

aliases.name: Property
aliases.comment:
An [animatable property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_animated_properties).

Many of these share a name and similar type with `Style` equivalents in the `Css` module, but they are different in that unlike `Style`s, animatable properties [are not compatible with `!important`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@keyframes#!important_in_a_keyframe) or various selectors or media queries.

If you need to use an experimental or vendor-prefixed animatable property, see [`custom`](#custom).

values.name: all
values.type: { compatible | value : String.String, all : Css.Structure.Compatible } -> Css.Animations.Property

values.name: backgroundColor
values.type: { compatible | value : String.String, color : Css.Structure.Compatible } -> Css.Animations.Property

values.name: borderBottom3
values.type: Css.Internal.Length compatible units -> Css.Internal.Length compatible units -> Css.Internal.Length compatible units -> Css.Animations.Property

values.name: custom
values.comment:
Create a custom animatable property with the given name and value. You can use this to define vendor-prefixed or experimental properties.

    custom "-moz-outline-radius" "25px"

**WARNING:** Some properties are not exposed in this module because they
are not animatable! This means browsers will refuse to animate them even if you pass them to this function.

MDN has [a list of the animatable properties](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_animated_properties).

values.name: keyframes
values.comment:
Specify a list of ( percentage, properties) tuples to use for
animation keyframes.

Pass the result to [`Css.animationName`](Css#animationName)!

`keyframes []` is equivalent to `none`.

name: Css.Media

aliases.name: Expression
aliases.comment:
A media expression.

An expression is a [media feature](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media#Media_features) with an optional value, which resolves to
either true or false.

In the media query `screen and (min-width: 768px)`,

  - `screen` is a media type,
  - `min-width` is a media feature, and
  - `(min-width: 768px)` is an expression.

aliases.name: MediaQuery

values.name: all
anyHover
values.comment:
Media feature [`any-hover`](https://drafts.csswg.org/mediaqueries/#any-input)
Queries the if any of user agent's input mechanisms have the ability to hover over elements
Accepts `none` or `canHover`.

    media (anyHover canHover) [ a [ Css.hover [ textDecoration underline ] ] ]

values.name: anyPointer
values.comment:
Media feature [`any-pointer`](https://drafts.csswg.org/mediaqueries/#any-input)
Queries the presence and accuracy of a pointing device, such as a mouse, touchscreen, or Wii remote.
Reflects the capabilities of the most capable input mechanism.
Accepts `none`, `fine`, and `coarse`.

    media (anyPointer coarse) [ a [ display block, Css.height (px 24) ] ]

values.name: canHover
values.comment:
The value [`hover`](https://drafts.csswg.org/mediaqueries/#valdef-media-hover-hover).

values.comment:
Media feature [`pointer`](https://drafts.csswg.org/mediaqueries/#pointer)
Queries the presence and accuracy of a pointing device, such as a mouse, touchscreen, or Wii remote.
Reflects the capabilities of the primary input mechanism.
Accepts `none`, `fine`, and `coarse`.

values.comment:

name: Css.Transitions
comment:
Define [CSS transitions](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Transitions).

    import Css exposing (..)
    import Css.Transitions exposing (easeInOut, transition)
    import Html
    import Html.Styled exposing (..)
    import Html.Styled.Attributes exposing (css)

    {-| In this case we are specifying a transition such that:

      - When the backgroundColor changes will interpolate between the current value and
        the new value over 1000 milliseconds with no delay and a default (ease) easing function
      - When the transform changes will interpolate between the current value and the
        new value over 500 milliseconds with no delay and an easeInOut easing function

    We are then using the `hover` function to specify that the backgroundColor and transform change on hover

    -}
    primaryButton =
        styled button
            [ backgroundColor (rgb 241 241 241)
            , transform (scaleX 1)
            , hover
                [ backgroundColor (rgb 220 220 220)
                , transform (scaleX 1.2)
                ]
            , transition
                [ Css.Transitions.backgroundColor 1000
                , Css.Transitions.transform3 500 0 easeInOut
                ]
            ]


# Transition

@docs Transition, transition


# Timing functions

These functions are used to specify the [CSS timing function](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transition-timing-function)
which describes how the animation speeds up or slows down over time.

@docs ease, linear, easeIn, easeOut, easeInOut, stepStart, stepEnd, cubicBezier


# Properties

These functions are used to create a transition, generally they come in three flavours, allowing you to specify:

  - Duration, delay and timing function
  - Duration and delay with default timing function (ease)
  - Just duration (default timing function and no delay)

An example of this would be the [`background3`](#background3), [`background2`](#background2) and [`background`](#background) functions

unions.name: Transition
unions.comment:
This describes all of the aspects of a [CSS transition](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transition), which will then be
compiled down to a string and added as a style property on elements

  - [animation](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_animated_properties): Which property to animate
  - [duration](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transition-duration): The total time that the animation should take from start to end
  - [delay](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transition-delay): Delay before the animation starts
  - [timing](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transition-timing-function): CSS timing function which dictates how the animation speed varies over time

values.name: transition
values.comment:
This function is used to batch up a list of supplied transitions that have been created (using the property functions listed below) and then produce a [`Css.Style`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/rtfeldman/elm-css/latest/Css#Style).
This can then be used with other functions (such as [`Html.Styled.Attributes.css`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/rtfeldman/elm-css/latest/Html-Styled-Attributes#css)) to add the desired transitions to elements / classes as required.

name: Html.Styled

aliases.name: Attribute
aliases.comment:
Set attributes on your `Html`. Learn more in the
[`Html.Attributes`](Html-Attributes) module.

aliases.name: Html
aliases.comment:
Styled [`Html`](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/html/latest/Html#Html).
You can convert from this to the normal [`Html`](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/html/latest/Html#Html) type from [`elm-lang/html`](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/html/latest)
(which is a type alias for [`VirtualDom.Node`](https://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/virtual-dom/latest/VirtualDom#Node))
by using [`toUnstyled`](#toUnstyled).
You can convert the other way using [`fromUnstyled`](#fromUnstyled).

values.name: a
values.comment: Represents a hyperlink, linking to another resource.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: abbr
values.comment:
Represents an abbreviation or an acronym; the expansion of the
abbreviation can be represented in the title attribute.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: address
values.comment: Defines a section containing contact information.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: article
values.comment:
Defines self-contained content that could exist independently of the rest
of the content.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: aside
values.comment:
Defines some content loosely related to the page content. If it is removed,
the remaining content still makes sense.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: audio
values.comment: Represents a sound or audio stream.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: b
values.comment:
Represents a text which to which attention is drawn for utilitarian
purposes. It doesn't convey extra importance and doesn't imply an alternate
voice.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: bdi
values.comment:
Represents text that must be isolated from its surrounding for
bidirectional text formatting. It allows embedding a span of text with a
different, or unknown, directionality.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: bdo
values.comment:
Represents the directionality of its children, in order to explicitly
override the Unicode bidirectional algorithm.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: blockquote
values.comment: Represents a content that is quoted from another source.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: br
values.comment: Represents a line break.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: button
values.comment: Represents a button.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: canvas
values.comment: Represents a bitmap area for graphics rendering.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: caption
values.comment: Represents the title of a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: cite
values.comment: Represents the title of a work.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: code
values.comment: Represents computer code.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: col
values.comment: Represents a column of a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: colgroup
values.comment: Represents a set of one or more columns of a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: datalist
values.comment: Represents a set of predefined options for other controls.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: dd
values.comment: Represents the definition of the terms immediately listed before it.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: del
values.comment: Defines a removal from the document.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: details
values.comment:
Represents a widget from which the user can obtain additional information
or controls.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: dfn
values.comment:
Represents a term whose definition is contained in its nearest ancestor
content.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: div
values.comment: Represents a generic container with no special meaning.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: dl
values.comment:
Defines a definition list, that is, a list of terms and their associated
definitions.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: dt
values.comment: Represents a term defined by the next `dd`.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: em
values.comment: Represents emphasized text, like a stress accent.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: embed
values.comment:
Represents a integration point for an external, often non-HTML,
application or interactive content.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: fieldset
values.comment: Represents a set of controls.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: figcaption
values.comment: Represents the legend of a figure.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: figure
values.comment: Represents a figure illustrated as part of the document.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: footer
values.comment:
Defines the footer for a page or section. It often contains a copyright
notice, some links to legal information, or addresses to give feedback.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: form
values.comment:
Represents a form, consisting of controls, that can be submitted to a
server for processing.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.comment:
Defines the header of a page or section. It often contains a logo, the

values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: hr
values.comment:
Represents a thematic break between paragraphs of a section or article or
any longer content.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: i
values.comment:
Represents some text in an alternate voice or mood, or at least of
different quality, such as a taxonomic designation, a technical term, an
idiomatic phrase, a thought, or a ship name.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: iframe
values.comment: Embedded an HTML document.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: img
values.comment: Represents an image.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: input
values.comment: Represents a typed data field allowing the user to edit the data.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: ins
values.comment: Defines an addition to the document.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: kbd
values.comment:
Represents user input, often from the keyboard, but not necessarily; it
may represent other input, like transcribed voice commands.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: label
values.comment: Represents the caption of a form control.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: legend
values.comment: Represents the caption for a `fieldset`.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: li
values.comment: Defines a item of an enumeration list.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: main_
values.comment:
Defines the main or important content in the document. There is only one
`main` element in the document.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the messages produced by some `Html`. In the following example,
we have `viewButton` that produces `()` messages, and we transform those values
into `Msg` values in `view`.

    type Msg
        = Left
        | Right

    view : model -> Html Msg
    view model =
        div []
            [ map (\_ -> Left) (viewButton "Left")
            , map (\_ -> Right) (viewButton "Right")
            ]

    viewButton : String -> Html ()
    viewButton name =
        button [ onClick () ] [ text name ]

This should not come in handy too often. Definitely read [this][reuse] before
deciding if this is what you want.

[reuse]: https://guide.elm-lang.org/reuse/

values.name: mark
values.comment:
Represents text highlighted for reference purposes, that is for its
relevance in another context.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: math
values.comment: Defines a mathematical formula.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: menu
values.comment: Represents a list of commands.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: menuitem
values.comment: Represents a command that the user can invoke.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: meter
values.comment:
Represents a scalar measurement (or a fractional value), within a known
range.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: nav
values.comment: Defines a section that contains only navigation links.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: node
values.comment:
General way to create HTML nodes. It is used to define all of the helper
functions in this library.

    div : List (Attribute msg) -> List (Html msg) -> Html msg
    div attributes children =
        node "div" attributes children

You can use this to create custom nodes if you need to create something that
is not covered by the helper functions in this library.
values.type: String.String -> List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: object
values.comment:
Represents an external resource, which is treated as an image, an HTML
sub-document, or an external resource to be processed by a plug-in.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: ol
values.comment: Defines an ordered list of items.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: optgroup
values.comment: Represents a set of options, logically grouped.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: option
values.comment:
Represents an option in a `select` element or a suggestion of a `datalist`
element.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: output
values.comment: Represents the result of a calculation.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: p
values.comment: Defines a portion that should be displayed as a paragraph.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: param
values.comment: Defines parameters for use by plug-ins invoked by `object` elements.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: pre
values.comment:
Indicates that its content is preformatted and that this format must be
preserved.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: progress
values.comment: Represents the completion progress of a task.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: q
values.comment: Represents an inline quotation.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: rp
values.comment:
Represents parenthesis around a ruby annotation, used to display the
annotation in an alternate way by browsers not supporting the standard display
for annotations.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: rt
values.comment: Represents the text of a ruby annotation.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: ruby
values.comment:
Represents content to be marked with ruby annotations, short runs of text
presented alongside the text. This is often used in conjunction with East Asian
language where the annotations act as a guide for pronunciation, like the
Japanese furigana.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: s
values.comment: Represents content that is no longer accurate or relevant.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: samp
values.comment: Represents the output of a program or a computer.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: section
values.comment: Defines a section in a document.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: select
values.comment: Represents a control allowing selection among a set of options.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: small
values.comment:
Represents a side comment, that is, text like a disclaimer or a
copyright, which is not essential to the comprehension of the document.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: source
values.comment:
Allows authors to specify alternative media resources for media elements
like `video` or `audio`.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: span
values.comment:
Represents text with no specific meaning. This has to be used when no other
text-semantic element conveys an adequate meaning, which, in this case, is
often brought by global attributes like `class`, `lang`, or `dir`.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: strong
values.comment: Represents especially important text.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: styled
values.comment:
Takes a function that creates an element, and pre-applies styles to it.
bigButton : List (Attribute msg) -> List (Html msg) -> Html msg
bigButton =
styled button
[ padding (px 30)
, fontWeight bold
]
view : Model -> Html msg
view model =
[ text "These two buttons are identical:"
, bigButton [][ text "Hi!" ]
, button [ css [ padding (px 30), fontWeight bold ] ][ text "Hi!" ]
][ text "These two buttons are identical:"
, bigButton [] [ text "Hi!" ]
, button [ css [ padding (px 30), fontWeight bold ] ] [] [ text "Hi!" ]
]
Here, the `bigButton` function we've defined using `styled button` is
identical to the normal `button` function, except that it has pre-applied
the attribute of `css [ padding (px 30), fontWeight bold ]`.
You can pass more attributes to `bigButton` as usual (including other `css`
attributes). They will be applied after the pre-applied styles.
values.type: (List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute a) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html b) -> Html.Styled.Html msg) -> List.List Css.Style -> List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute a) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html b) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: sub
values.comment: Represent a subscript.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: summary
values.comment: Represents a summary, caption, or legend for a given `details`.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: sup
values.comment: Represent a superscript.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: table
values.comment: Represents data with more than one dimension.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: tbody
values.comment: Represents the block of rows that describes the concrete data of a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: td
values.comment: Represents a data cell in a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: text
values.comment:
Just put plain text in the DOM. It will escape the string so that it appears
exactly as you specify.

    text "Hello World!"

values.name: textarea
values.comment: Represents a multiline text edit control.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: tfoot
values.comment: Represents the block of rows that describes the column summaries of a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: th
values.comment: Represents a header cell in a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: thead
values.comment: Represents the block of rows that describes the column labels of a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: time
values.comment:
Represents a date and time value; the machine-readable equivalent can be
represented in the datetime attribute.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: tr
values.comment: Represents a row of cells in a table.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: track
values.comment:
Allows authors to specify timed text track for media elements like `video`
or `audio`.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: u
values.comment:
Represents a non-textual annotation for which the conventional
presentation is underlining, such labeling the text as being misspelt or
labeling a proper name in Chinese text.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: ul
values.comment: Defines an unordered list of items.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: var
values.comment:
Represents a variable. Specific cases where it should be used include an
actual mathematical expression or programming context, an identifier
representing a constant, a symbol identifying a physical quantity, a function
parameter, or a mere placeholder in prose.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: video
values.comment: Represents a video, the associated audio and captions, and controls.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: wbr
values.comment:
Represents a line break opportunity, that is a suggested point for
wrapping text in order to improve readability of text split on several lines.
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List (Html.Styled.Html msg) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

name: Html.Styled.Attributes

values.name: accept
values.comment:
List of types the server accepts, typically a file type.
For `form` and `input`.

values.name: acceptCharset
values.comment: List of supported charsets in a `form`.

values.name: accesskey
values.comment: Defines a keyboard shortcut to activate or add focus to the element.

values.name: action
values.comment: The URI of a program that processes the information submitted via a `form`.

values.name: align
values.comment:
Specifies the horizontal alignment of a `caption`, `col`, `colgroup`,
`hr`, `iframe`, `img`, `table`, `tbody`, `td`, `tfoot`, `th`, `thead`, or
`tr`.

values.name: alt
values.comment:
Alternative text in case an image can't be displayed. Works with `img`,
`area`, and `input`.

values.name: attribute
values.comment:
Create _attributes_, like saying `domNode.setAttribute('class', 'greeting')`
in JavaScript.

    class : String -> Attribute msg
    class name =
        attribute "class" name

Read more about the difference between properties and attributes [here].

[here]: https://github.com/elm/html/blob/master/properties-vs-attributes.md

values.name: autocomplete
values.comment:
Indicates whether a `form` or an `input` can have their values automatically
completed by the browser.

values.name: autofocus
values.comment:
The element should be automatically focused after the page loaded.
For `button`, `input`, `select`, and `textarea`.

values.name: autoplay
values.comment: The `audio` or `video` should play as soon as possible.

values.name: checked
values.comment: Indicates whether an `input` of type checkbox is checked.

values.name: cite
values.comment:
Contains a URI which points to the source of the quote or change in a
`blockquote`, `del`, `ins`, or `q`.

values.name: class
values.comment:
Often used with CSS to style elements with common properties.

**Note:** You can have as many `class` and `classList` attributes as you want.
They all get applied, so if you say `[ class "notice", class "notice-seen" ]`
you will get both classes!

values.name: classList
values.comment:
This function makes it easier to build a space-separated class attribute.
Each class can easily be added and removed depending on the boolean value it
is paired with. For example, maybe we want a way to view notices:

    viewNotice : Notice -> Html msg
    viewNotice notice =
        div
            [ classList
                [ ( "notice", True )
                , ( "notice-important", notice.isImportant )
                , ( "notice-seen", notice.isSeen )
                ]
            ]
            [ text notice.content ]

**Note:** You can have as many `class` and `classList` attributes as you want.
They all get applied, so if you say `[ class "notice", class "notice-seen" ]`
you will get both classes!

values.name: cols
values.comment: Defines the number of columns in a `textarea`.

values.name: colspan
values.comment:
The colspan attribute defines the number of columns a cell should span.
For `td` and `th`.

values.name: contenteditable
values.comment: Indicates whether the element's content is editable.

values.name: contextmenu
values.comment:
Defines the ID of a `menu` element which will serve as the element's
context menu.

values.name: controls
values.comment:
Indicates whether the browser should show playback controls for the `audio`
or `video`.

values.name: coords
values.comment:
A set of values specifying the coordinates of the hot-spot region in an
`area`. Needs to be paired with a `shape` attribute to be meaningful.

values.name: css
values.comment:
Apply styles to an element.
See the [`Css` module documentation](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/rtfeldman/elm-css/latest/Css) for an overview of how to use this function.

values.name: datetime
values.comment:
Indicates the date and time associated with the element.
For `del`, `ins`, `time`.

values.name: default
values.comment:
Indicates that the `track` should be enabled unless the user's preferences
indicate something different.

values.name: dir
values.comment:
Defines the text direction. Allowed values are ltr (Left-To-Right) or rtl
(Right-To-Left).

values.name: disabled
values.comment:
Indicates whether the user can interact with a `button`, `fieldset`,
`input`, `optgroup`, `option`, `select` or `textarea`.

values.name: download
values.comment:
Indicates that clicking an `a` and `area` will download the resource
directly. The `String` argument determins the name of the downloaded file.
Say the file you are serving is named `hats.json`.

    download "" -- hats.json

    download "my-hats.json" -- my-hats.json

    download "snakes.json" -- snakes.json

The empty `String` says to just name it whatever it was called on the server.

values.name: draggable
values.comment: Defines whether the element can be dragged.

values.name: dropzone
values.comment: Indicates that the element accept the dropping of content on it.

values.name: enctype
values.comment:
How `form` data should be encoded when submitted with the POST method.
Options include: application/x-www-form-urlencoded, multipart/form-data, and
text/plain.

values.name: for
values.comment:
The element ID described by this `label` or the element IDs that are used
for an `output`.

values.name: form
values.comment:
Indicates the element ID of the `form` that owns this particular `button`,
`fieldset`, `input`, `label`, `meter`, `object`, `output`, `progress`,
`select`, or `textarea`.

values.name: fromUnstyled
values.comment:
Convert from an unstyled `Attribute` to a styled one.

Note that there is no `toUnstyled` for Attributes! This is because the process
of going from styled to unstyled involves adding a `<style>` element to the DOM,
and Attributes cannot do that. So it would be impossible to implement
`toUnstyled` for Attributes without throwing the styles away - which is definitely
undesirable!

values.name: headers
values.comment:
A space separated list of element IDs indicating which `th` elements are
headers for this cell. For `td` and `th`.

values.name: height
values.comment:
Declare the height of a `canvas`, `embed`, `iframe`, `img`, `input`,
`object`, or `video`.

values.name: hidden
values.comment: Indicates the relevance of an element.

values.name: href
values.comment: The URL of a linked resource, such as `a`, `area`, `base`, or `link`.

values.name: hreflang
values.comment: Two-letter language code of the linked resource of an `a`, `area`, or `link`.

values.name: id
values.comment:
Often used with CSS to style a specific element. The value of this
attribute must be unique.

values.name: ismap
values.comment:
When an `img` is a descendant of an `a` tag, the `ismap` attribute
indicates that the click location should be added to the parent `a`'s href as
a query string.

values.name: kind
values.comment: Specifies the kind of text `track`.

values.name: lang
values.comment: Defines the language used in the element.

values.name: list
values.comment:
Associates an `input` with a `datalist` tag. The datalist gives some
pre-defined options to suggest to the user as they interact with an input.
The value of the list attribute must match the id of a `datalist` node.
For `input`.

values.name: loop
values.comment:
Indicates whether the `audio` or `video` should start playing from the
start when it's finished.

values.name: manifest
values.comment: Specifies the URL of the cache manifest for an `html` tag.

values.name: map
values.comment: Transform the messages produced by an `Attribute`.

values.name: max
values.comment:
Indicates the maximum value allowed. When using an input of type number or
date, the max value must be a number or date. For `input`, `meter`, and `progress`.

values.name: maxlength
values.comment:
Defines the maximum number of characters allowed in an `input` or
`textarea`.

values.name: media
values.comment:
Specifies a hint of the target media of a `a`, `area`, `link`, `source`,
or `style`.

values.name: method
values.comment:
Defines which HTTP method to use when submitting a `form`. Can be GET
(default) or POST.

values.name: min
values.comment:
Indicates the minimum value allowed. When using an input of type number or
date, the min value must be a number or date. For `input` and `meter`.

values.name: minlength
values.comment:
Defines the minimum number of characters allowed in an `input` or
`textarea`.

values.name: multiple
values.comment:
Indicates whether multiple values can be entered in an `input` of type
email or file. Can also indicate that you can `select` many options.

values.name: name
values.comment:
Name of the element. For example used by the server to identify the fields
in form submits. For `button`, `form`, `fieldset`, `iframe`, `input`,
`object`, `output`, `select`, `textarea`, `map`, `meta`, and `param`.

values.name: novalidate
values.comment:
This attribute indicates that a `form` shouldn't be validated when
submitted.

values.name: pattern
values.comment:
Defines a regular expression which an `input`'s value will be validated
against.

values.name: ping
values.comment:
Specify a URL to send a short POST request to when the user clicks on an
`a` or `area`. Useful for monitoring and tracking.

values.name: placeholder
values.comment:
Provides a hint to the user of what can be entered into an `input` or
`textarea`.

values.name: poster
values.comment:
A URL indicating a poster frame to show until the user plays or seeks the
`video`.

values.name: preload
values.comment: Control how much of an `audio` or `video` resource should be preloaded.

values.name: property
values.comment:
Create _properties_, like saying `domNode.className = 'greeting'` in
JavaScript.

    import Json.Encode as Encode

    class : String -> Attribute msg
    class name =
        property "className" (Encode.string name)

Read more about the difference between properties and attributes [here].

[here]: https://github.com/elm/html/blob/master/properties-vs-attributes.md

values.name: pubdate
values.comment:
Indicates whether this date and time is the date of the nearest `article`
ancestor element. For `time`.

values.name: readonly
values.comment: Indicates whether an `input` or `textarea` can be edited.

values.name: rel
values.comment:
Specifies the relationship of the target object to the link object.
For `a`, `area`, `link`.

values.name: required
values.comment:
Indicates whether this element is required to fill out or not.
For `input`, `select`, and `textarea`.

values.name: reversed
values.comment:
Indicates whether an ordered list `ol` should be displayed in a descending
order instead of a ascending.

values.name: rows
values.comment: Defines the number of rows in a `textarea`.

values.name: rowspan
values.comment:
Defines the number of rows a table cell should span over.
For `td` and `th`.

values.name: sandbox
values.comment:
A space separated list of security restrictions you'd like to lift for an
`iframe`.

values.name: scope
values.comment:
Specifies the scope of a header cell `th`. Possible values are: col, row,
colgroup, rowgroup.

values.name: selected
values.comment: Defines which `option` will be selected on page load.

values.name: shape
values.comment:
Declare the shape of the clickable area in an `a` or `area`. Valid values
include: default, rect, circle, poly. This attribute can be paired with
`coords` to create more particular shapes.

values.name: size
values.comment:
For `input` specifies the width of an input in characters.

For `select` specifies the number of visible options in a drop-down list.

values.name: spellcheck
values.comment: Indicates whether spell checking is allowed for the element.

values.name: src
values.comment:
The URL of the embeddable content. For `audio`, `embed`, `iframe`, `img`,
`input`, `script`, `source`, `track`, and `video`.

values.name: srcdoc
values.comment:
An HTML document that will be displayed as the body of an `iframe`. It will
override the content of the `src` attribute if it has been specified.

values.name: srclang
values.comment: A two letter language code indicating the language of the `track` text data.

values.name: start
values.comment:
Defines the first number of an ordered list if you want it to be something
besides 1.

values.name: step
values.comment:
Add a step size to an `input`. Use `step "any"` to allow any floating-point
number to be used in the input.

values.name: style
values.comment:
**NOTE:** If you're using `elm-css`, you **probably do not want this!**

This is the `style` **attribute**, which has higher precedence than anything
`elm-css` does. It's probably best to use this as a workaround only.

    Specify a style.

    greeting : Node msg
    greeting =
      div
        [ style "background-color" "red"
        , style "height" "90px"
        , style "width" "100%"
        ]
        [ text "Hello!"
        ]

There is no `Html.Styles` module because best practices for working with HTML
suggest that this should primarily be specified in CSS files. So the general
recommendation is to use this function lightly.

values.name: tabindex
values.comment:
Overrides the browser's default tab order and follows the one specified
instead.

values.name: target
values.comment:
Specify where the results of clicking an `a`, `area`, `base`, or `form`
should appear. Possible special values include:

  - \_blank — a new window or tab
  - \_self — the same frame (this is default)
  - \_parent — the parent frame
  - \_top — the full body of the window

You can also give the name of any `frame` you have created.

values.name: title
values.comment: Text to be displayed in a tooltip when hovering over the element.

values.name: type_
values.comment:
Defines the type of a `button`, `input`, `embed`, `object`, `script`,
`source`, `style`, or `menu`.

values.name: usemap
values.comment:
Specify the hash name reference of a `map` that should be used for an `img`
or `object`. A hash name reference is a hash symbol followed by the element's name or id.
E.g. `"#planet-map"`.

values.name: value
values.comment:
Defines a default value which will be displayed in a `button`, `option`,
`input`, `li`, `meter`, `progress`, or `param`.

values.name: width
values.comment:
Declare the width of a `canvas`, `embed`, `iframe`, `img`, `input`,
`object`, or `video`.

values.name: wrap
values.comment:
Indicates whether the text should be wrapped in a `textarea`. Possible
values are "hard" and "soft".

name: Html.Styled.Events

values.name: custom
values.comment:
Create an event listener that may [`stopPropagation`][stop] or
[`preventDefault`][prevent].

[stop]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/stopPropagation
[prevent]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault

**Note:** If you need something even more custom (like capture phase) check
out the lower-level event API in `elm/virtual-dom`.
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder { message : msg, stopPropagation : Basics.Bool, preventDefault : Basics.Bool } -> Html.Styled.Attribute msg

values.name: keyCode
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.keyCode`. This helps you define
keyboard listeners like this:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onKeyUp : (Int -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onKeyUp tagger =
        on "keyup" (Json.map tagger keyCode)

**Note:** It looks like the spec is moving away from `event.keyCode` and
towards `event.key`. Once this is supported in more browsers, we may add
helpers here for `onKeyUp`, `onKeyDown`, `onKeyPress`, etc.

values.name: on
values.comment:
Create a custom event listener. Normally this will not be necessary, but
you have the power! Here is how `onClick` is defined for example:

    import Json.Decode as Decode

    onClick : msg -> Attribute msg
    onClick message =
        on "click" (Decode.succeed message)

The first argument is the event name in the same format as with JavaScript's
[`addEventListener`][aEL] function.

The second argument is a JSON decoder. Read more about these [here][decoder].
When an event occurs, the decoder tries to turn the event object into an Elm
value. If successful, the value is routed to your `update` function. In the
case of `onClick` we always just succeed with the given `message`.

If this is confusing, work through the [Elm Architecture Tutorial][tutorial].
It really helps!

[aEL]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener
[decoder]: /packages/elm/json/latest/Json-Decode
[tutorial]: https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial/

**Note:** This creates a [passive] event listener, enabling optimizations for
touch, scroll, and wheel events in some browsers.

[passive]: https://github.com/WICG/EventListenerOptions/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md

values.name: onCheck
values.comment:
Detect [change](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/change)
events on checkboxes. It will grab the boolean value from `event.target.checked`
on any input event.

Check out [`targetChecked`](#targetChecked) for more details on how this works.

values.name: onInput
values.comment:
Detect [input](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/input)
events for things like text fields or text areas.

For more details on how `onInput` works, check out [`targetValue`](#targetValue).

**Note 1:** It grabs the **string** value at `event.target.value`, so it will
not work if you need some other information. For example, if you want to track
inputs on a range slider, make a custom handler with [`on`](#on).

**Note 2:** It uses `stopPropagationOn` internally to always stop propagation
of the event. This is important for complicated reasons explained [here][1] and
[here][2].

[1]: /packages/elm/virtual-dom/latest/VirtualDom#Handler
[2]: https://github.com/elm/virtual-dom/issues/125

values.name: onSubmit
values.comment:
Detect a [submit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/submit)
event with [`preventDefault`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault)
in order to prevent the form from changing the page’s location. If you need
different behavior, create a custom event handler.

values.name: preventDefaultOn
values.comment:
Create an event listener that may [`preventDefault`][prevent]. Your decoder
must produce a message and a `Bool` that decides if `preventDefault` should
be called.

For example, the `onSubmit` function in this library _always_ prevents the
default behavior:

[prevent]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault

    onSubmit : msg -> Attribute msg
    onSubmit msg =
        preventDefaultOn "submit" (Json.map alwaysPreventDefault (Json.succeed msg))

    alwaysPreventDefault : msg -> ( msg, Bool )
    alwaysPreventDefault msg =
        ( msg, True )
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder ( msg, Basics.Bool ) -> Html.Styled.Attribute msg

values.name: stopPropagationOn
values.comment:
Create an event listener that may [`stopPropagation`][stop]. Your decoder
must produce a message and a `Bool` that decides if `stopPropagation` should
be called.

[stop]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/stopPropagation

**Note:** This creates a [passive] event listener, enabling optimizations for
touch, scroll, and wheel events in some browsers.

[passive]: https://github.com/WICG/EventListenerOptions/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder ( msg, Basics.Bool ) -> Html.Styled.Attribute msg

values.name: targetChecked
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.target.checked`. We use this to define
`onCheck` as follows:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onCheck : (Bool -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onCheck tagger =
        on "input" (Json.map tagger targetChecked)

values.name: targetValue
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.target.value`. We use this to define
`onInput` as follows:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onInput : (String -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onInput tagger =
        stopPropagationOn "input" <|
            Json.map alwaysStop (Json.map tagger targetValue)

    alwaysStop : a -> ( a, Bool )
    alwaysStop x =
        ( x, True )

You probably will never need this, but hopefully it gives some insights into
how to make custom event handlers.

name: Html.Styled.Keyed
comment:
A keyed node helps optimize cases where children are getting added, moved,
removed, etc. Common examples include:

  - The user can delete items from a list.
  - The user can create new items in a list.
  - You can sort a list based on name or date or whatever.

When you use a keyed node, every child is paired with a string identifier. This
makes it possible for the underlying diffing algorithm to reuse nodes more
efficiently.


# Keyed Nodes

@docs node


# Commonly Keyed Nodes

@docs ol, ul

values.name: node
values.comment:
Works just like `Html.node`, but you add a unique identifier to each child
node. You want this when you have a list of nodes that is changing: adding
nodes, removing nodes, etc. In these cases, the unique identifiers help make
the DOM modifications more efficient.
values.type: String.String -> List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List ( String.String, Html.Styled.Html msg ) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: ol
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List ( String.String, Html.Styled.Html msg ) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: ul
values.type: List.List (Html.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List ( String.String, Html.Styled.Html msg ) -> Html.Styled.Html msg

name: Html.Styled.Lazy
comment:
**NOTE:** `Html.Lazy` goes up to `lazy8`, but `Html.Styled.Lazy` can only go
up to `lazy7` because it uses one of the arguments to track styling info.

Since all Elm functions are pure we have a guarantee that the same input

will always result in the same output. This module gives us tools to be lazy
about building `Html` that utilize this fact.

Rather than immediately applying functions to their arguments, the `lazy`
functions just bundle the function and arguments up for later. When diffing
the old and new virtual DOM, it checks to see if all the arguments are equal
by reference. If so, it skips calling the function!

This is a really cheap test and often makes things a lot faster, but definitely
benchmark to be sure!

@docs lazy, lazy2, lazy3, lazy4, lazy5, lazy6, lazy7

values.name: lazy
values.comment:
A performance optimization that delays the building of virtual DOM nodes.

Calling `(view model)` will definitely build some virtual DOM, perhaps a lot of
it. Calling `(lazy view model)` delays the call until later. During diffing, we
can check to see if `model` is referentially equal to the previous value used,
and if so, we just stop. No need to build up the tree structure and diff it,
we know if the input to `view` is the same, the output must be the same!

values.name: lazy2
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on two arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> Html.Styled.Html msg) -> a -> b -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: lazy3
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on three arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> Html.Styled.Html msg) -> a -> b -> c -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: lazy4
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on four arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> Html.Styled.Html msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: lazy5
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on five arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> Html.Styled.Html msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: lazy6
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on six arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> Html.Styled.Html msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> Html.Styled.Html msg

values.name: lazy7
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on seven arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> Html.Styled.Html msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> Html.Styled.Html msg

name: Svg.Styled.Attributes

values.name: css
values.comment:
Apply styles to an element.

See the [`Css` module documentation](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/rtfeldman/elm-css/latest/Css) for an overview of how to use this function.

name: Svg.Styled.Events

values.name: custom
values.comment:
Create an event listener that may [`stopPropagation`][stop] or
[`preventDefault`][prevent].

[stop]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/stopPropagation
[prevent]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault

**Note:** If you need something even more custom (like capture phase) check
out the lower-level event API in `elm/virtual-dom`.
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder { message : msg, stopPropagation : Basics.Bool, preventDefault : Basics.Bool } -> VirtualDom.Styled.Attribute msg

values.name: on
values.comment:
Create a custom event listener. Normally this will not be necessary, but
you have the power! Here is how `onClick` is defined for example:

    import Json.Decode as Decode

    onClick : msg -> Attribute msg
    onClick message =
        on "click" (Decode.succeed message)

The first argument is the event name in the same format as with JavaScript's
[`addEventListener`][aEL] function.

The second argument is a JSON decoder. Read more about these [here][decoder].
When an event occurs, the decoder tries to turn the event object into an Elm
value. If successful, the value is routed to your `update` function. In the
case of `onClick` we always just succeed with the given `message`.

If this is confusing, work through the [Elm Architecture Tutorial][tutorial].
It really helps!

[aEL]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener
[decoder]: /packages/elm/json/latest/Json-Decode
[tutorial]: https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial/

**Note:** This creates a [passive] event listener, enabling optimizations for
touch, scroll, and wheel events in some browsers.

[passive]: https://github.com/WICG/EventListenerOptions/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md

values.name: preventDefaultOn
values.comment:
Create an event listener that may [`preventDefault`][prevent]. Your decoder
must produce a message and a `Bool` that decides if `preventDefault` should
be called.

For example, the `onSubmit` function in this library _always_ prevents the
default behavior:

[prevent]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault

    onSubmit : msg -> Attribute msg
    onSubmit msg =
        preventDefaultOn "submit" (Json.map alwaysPreventDefault (Json.succeed msg))

    alwaysPreventDefault : msg -> ( msg, Bool )
    alwaysPreventDefault msg =
        ( msg, True )
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder ( msg, Basics.Bool ) -> VirtualDom.Styled.Attribute msg

values.name: stopPropagationOn
values.comment:
Create an event listener that may [`stopPropagation`][stop]. Your decoder
must produce a message and a `Bool` that decides if `stopPropagation` should
be called.

[stop]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/stopPropagation

**Note:** This creates a [passive] event listener, enabling optimizations for
touch, scroll, and wheel events in some browsers.

[passive]: https://github.com/WICG/EventListenerOptions/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md
values.type: String.String -> Json.Decode.Decoder ( msg, Basics.Bool ) -> VirtualDom.Styled.Attribute msg

name: Svg.Styled.Keyed
comment:
A keyed node helps optimize cases where children are getting added, moved,
removed, etc. Common examples include:

  - The user can delete items from a list.
  - The user can create new items in a list.
  - You can sort a list based on name or date or whatever.

When you use a keyed node, every child is paired with a string identifier. This
makes it possible for the underlying diffing algorithm to reuse nodes more
efficiently.


# Keyed Nodes

@docs node

values.name: node
values.comment:
Works just like `Svg.node`, but you add a unique identifier to each child
node. You want this when you have a list of nodes that is changing: adding
nodes, removing nodes, etc. In these cases, the unique identifiers help make
the DOM modifications more efficient.
values.type: String.String -> List.List (Svg.Styled.Attribute msg) -> List.List ( String.String, Svg.Styled.Svg msg ) -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg

name: Svg.Styled.Lazy
comment:
**NOTE:** `Svg.Lazy` goes up to `lazy8`, but `Svg.Styled.Lazy` can only go
up to `lazy7` because it uses one of the arguments to track styling info.

Since all Elm functions are pure we have a guarantee that the same input
will always result in the same output. This module gives us tools to be lazy
about building `Svg` that utilize this fact.

Rather than immediately applying functions to their arguments, the `lazy`
functions just bundle the function and arguments up for later. When diffing
the old and new virtual DOM, it checks to see if all the arguments are equal.
If so, it skips calling the function!

This is a really cheap test and often makes things a lot faster, but definitely
benchmark to be sure!

@docs lazy, lazy2, lazy3, lazy4, lazy5, lazy6, lazy7

values.name: lazy
values.comment:
A performance optimization that delays the building of virtual DOM nodes.

Calling `(view model)` will definitely build some virtual DOM, perhaps a lot of
it. Calling `(lazy view model)` delays the call until later. During diffing, we
can check to see if `model` is referentially equal to the previous value used,
and if so, we just stop. No need to build up the tree structure and diff it,
we know if the input to `view` is the same, the output must be the same!

values.name: lazy2
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on two arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg) -> a -> b -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg

values.name: lazy3
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on three arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg) -> a -> b -> c -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg

values.name: lazy4
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on four arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg

values.name: lazy5
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on five arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg

values.name: lazy6
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on six arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg

values.name: lazy7
values.comment: Same as `lazy` but checks on seven arguments.
values.type: (a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg) -> a -> b -> c -> d -> e -> f -> g -> Svg.Styled.Svg msg
